S.H.

WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. George Johnson
Address: 483 Walnut St., Winnipeg, Man.
Birthplace: Denmark

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1890
Where did you set up housekeeping? Langenburg, Sask.
Where had you been living before that? Winnipeg, Carberry, Melbourne (1890)
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a week by ox cart or sleigh.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
sugar, tea, coffee, rice, flour, syrup, salt, peas, beans

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Grist Flour
Took wheat (green or otherwise) to mill at Millwood
In what quantities did you buy it? 5 x 100 lbs. of wheat
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use Graham flour? Not at all
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes, 20 miles away
What year? 1890
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Did not use it
What other grain products did you use? Barley
Cornmeal? No Whole wheat? No Farina? No
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Did not use it
How did you grind it? X

1. IMMIGRATION HISTORY

That year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1890.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Laurierburg, Saskatchewan.
There had you been living before that? Winnipeg, Manitoba (1888).
For how many years did you live there?
How far from it to your nearest store? 3 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once or twice a week by ox cart.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Sugar, tea, coffee, rice, flour, syrup, salt, peas, beans.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

Have brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Gaist Flour.
To what quantities did you buy 162 ... New Year's Day ... as ... Wheat.
That was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $5.00.
How much did you use regular flour?
Whole wheat flour? Yes.
Was flour milled locally? Yes.
Was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Did not use it.
That other grain products did you use? Barley.
Corn meal? No.
Other? No.
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Did not use it.
How did you grind it?
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...2 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? ...$1.00

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ...Brown sugar made by storekeeper

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? ...Bulk, look out own container

At what price? ...or made our own from brown sugar.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? ...Kept cows

Butter? ...Produced our own

Eggs? ...Produced our own

What was the price of butter? ...$0.50

Did you pack eggs for winter? ...Yes

Did you make butter? ...Yes

Cheese? ...Yes

What kind of cheese? ...Compared to Ontario cheese

Also a white cheese similar to nippy craft cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ...Killed a pig in fall, beef (our own), wild game & birds

How did you get fresh meat? ...Only when we had a bear to kill

How often did you get fresh meat? ...Had little but used chickens

How did you preserve meat? ...Had a deep well for fresh meat

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? ...Not for many years

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? ...Yes

What kinds? ...Prairie chicken, wild ducks

For how long? ...For many years

What part did fish play in the family diet? ...No water in neighborhood, but dealer sometimes drove by

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? ...Cured

Kinds? ...Mostly white same pike...
3. **SUGAR AND SUGAR**

In what quantity did you buy? (Was ever?) 2 lbs.

What was the price? For a tax paid, what was the price? $1.00.

That brand of sugar was used by whom? Mrs. Johnson.

Did you buy sugar at the store? Yes.

4. **BUTTER PRICES**

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Kept cows.

Butter? Produced our own.

That was the price of butter? $1.00.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Did you make cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Buttered cheese.

Also a white cheese similar to nippy craft cheese.

5. **MEAT AND FISH**

That was your meat supply in the early days? Beef, pork, and chicken.

How often did you get fresh meat? Daily.

Did you raise your own? No.

Did you have a deep well for fresh water?

Purchased for another.

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? No.

For how long? Five years.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kind? Poultry.

Did you raise ducks? Yes.

For how long? Five years.

Did you play in the family plot? No.

Did you have a neighborhood butchery? Yes.

Was the flesh fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kindly? Mostly white.
Coffee made from burned grain was commonly called "Sin and Misery."

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? No..........
peas? No... corn? No... beans? No... Saskatoons? No... other foods? ..................................................
What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1896...........
What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1918........
What year did you first preserve meat by canning? Never........
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? Canning..........
To what extent? Two Hundred quarts until 1921........
Did you make your own vinegar? No... Store keeper did.
Coffee made from burned grain was commonly called "Sin and Misery."

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Nearly everything in bulk at first. 1888
Ginger snaps came out of a barrel, so did fig bars etc.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1890—
Sept.
Breakfast—Bread and milk
Dinner—Vegs, fried bacon
milk pudding
Supper—Toast & syrup
leftover meat, eggs

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

1891........Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

1891 is the earliest we can recall.
Roast goose—raisin filling
Vegs.
Christmas cake raised with yeast & had
peels raisins—sort of raised fruit loaf.
Coffee

19. Have you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

NO. We always had plenty of meat—
very often moose or elk. Also dairy products.
Nearly everything in bulk at first. So did fig bars etc.

Ginger snaps came out of a barrel so did fig bars etc.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest years. Include the names of the foodstuffs used.

Breakfast - Bread and milk

Supper - Toast and milk pudding

Dinner - Eggs, fried bacon

Train baby boys

Sept.

1890-91

Roast goose - raisin filling

Vegs.

Christmas cake raised with yeast - half

peels raisins - sort of raised fruit loaf

Coffee

19. Have you ever resorted to eating starvation rations or any other means of obtaining food? Give details.

No. We always had plenty of meat.

Very often moose or elk. Also dairy products.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

About 1900 when we did not grow as much because we then lived in a tiny village.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

All the answers given here were contributed by senior members of a family of nine surviving members of eleven Johnsons who came from Denmark originally. Mrs. George Johnson (our mother) is dead but we have at a Christmas party filled in the answers which she could have supplied. The four eldest were born in Denmark.

Re - Lighting. In the earliest days we had tall candles which were made in a queer contraption which could turn out 48 candles (tall) at once - (a lead candle mold in form).
About 1900 when we did not grow as much because we then lived in a fairy village.
